REFERENDUM


2.32 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Amendment [17th April, 1962] to Question [17th April, 1962],

    "That this Assembly solemnly assures the citizens of Singapore that before arrangements are finalised for a closer relationship with the Federation of Malaya and/or the Borneo territories, and before any request is made b the Government of Singapore to the British Government for transfer of territorial sovereignty over Singapore to the Federation of Malaya or Malaysia, the wishes of the voters of Singapore will be ascertained by referendum and the Government will act in accordance with the views of our citizens so expressed.".-(Mr David Marshall).

    Which Amendment was,

    `To leave out from "That" in line 1 to the end and insert -

    "in view of the Government's clearly stated stand on the question of merger, this House welcomes the Government's introduction of the Singapore National Referendum Bill in order to hold a referendum to ascertain the wishes of the people on the mode and manner of the inevitable reunification of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya before arrangements are finalised and before any request is made by the Government of Singapore to the British Government for transfer

Column: 848

of territorial sovereignty over Singapore to the Federation of Malaya or Malaysia".'- (The Deputy Prime Minister-Dr Toh Chin Chye).

    Question again proposed, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

2.34 p.m.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam (Choa Chu Kang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir I mentioned yesterday that the P.A.P. was just like Hitler a few years ago. The S.P.A. is no different from Eichmann. The P.A.P. wants to write oft with one stroke of the pen the will and views of the people of Singapore on tile question of a national referendum. The S.P.A. is abetting in this intrique. It is now singing the same tune and trying to seek concord out of differences.

    The Minister for Culture yesterday said that many people believed in merger, but what should be the form of merger? That is the question to be decided upon. The Member for Farrer Park also said that, in principle, everybody supported merger. The question is, how is tile merger to be carried out and what type of merger will it be? The Government should consult the people on the question of merger. Sir, the speeches of these two fellow travellers are very attractive and may appeal to some people. They may appear to be very democratic. But if we go more carefully and deeply into this, we will have no difficulty in seeing through their tactic, which is to confuse white with black, or, pointing at a stag, say that it is a horse. If the Government is sincere in its wish to consult the people and let them decide on the form of merger, then, first of all, it must collect all the views and concepts of the various political Parties on this question of merger. The Government should then ask the people which type of merger they want, i.e., the type that is formulated by which political Party. The Government must abide by the decision of the people and proceed to negotiate with the Federation Government on that basis. That is the only way for the Government to consult the will and the opinions of the people.

    But, Mr Speaker, Sir, the P.A.P. secretly proceeded with its talks with the

Column: 849

Federation Government on the question of merger before consulting the people, and now they have presented this so-called White Paper on merger. Now what the Government should seek is whether the people agree to or oppose their White Paper on merger, i.e., the form of merger the people are faced with, for their decision today. Mr Speaker, Sir, this question is just like a barrel of rice before it is cooked, that is, the opinions and the views of all should be consulted. What kind of rice are we going to cook, Teochew porridge or Kongfu porridge? But now the P.A.P. is presenting the rice already cooked and burnt to the people and is asking their views on it. Mr Speaker, Sir, the people are now asked to decide whether or not they accept the burnt rice that is cooked by the P.A.P. (that is something already done) and not on what kind of rice they are going to eat. Therefore, Mr Speaker, Sir, there should only be one question at the national referendum - whether the people want this White Paper on merger.

    Mr Speaker: Order. The hon. Member is perhaps in order if, in his speech, he makes passing reference to the White Paper and urges that it should be put to the referendum. But I might remind him that there was an amendment by the Member for Queenstown which specifically asked that the question be put to the referendum, and that amendment has been lost. Therefore, there cannot be a debate now on whether or not that question should be put. As I say, a passing reference to allow for Continuity Of a Member's speech is permitted. But not a debate now on whether or not that question should be put.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I had just concluded what I wanted to say on that point.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Farrer Park also said yesterday that a national referendum is meant for the Government to seek the views of the people on a certain question, so as to enable the Government and the legislature to know what kind of merger is to be adopted and what they should do on a certain issue. If there is only one question on the ballot paper put before the people, it is not enough because, if that is so, then it is not possible to get the

Column: 850

views of the people on a certain issue. Mr Speaker, Sir, that is what the Member for Fairer Park said. The Front benches of the Government on many occasions have also made the same arguments as those advanced by the Member for Farrer Park. All these arguments are not worth rebutting.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Deputy Prime Minister on 16th of March, during the course of the debate on the National Referendum Bill, pointed to the national referendum held in New Zealand as an example. That referendum concerned the question whether bars and restaurants should carry on their business after 6 p.m. The question before the electorate in New Zealand was whether after 6 p.m, bars and restaurants should close their doors, and not whether they should close at a certain hour or whether after 6 p.m., what kind of liquors should be sold.

    Mr Speaker, on the 1st of October last year, the New Zealand Government put a question to the people to decide whether they wanted to ban nuclear weapons. The question was not how to ban them or to limit their number. Mr Speaker, Sir, the independence of Algeria is inevitable. According to the Associated Press news from Paris, on 8th April, the question put by the French Government in a referendum was whether they would agree to the Algerian peace proposals put forward by the President of France, General de Gaulle. In other words, the French people were asked to decide whether they agreed to the French/Algerian cease-fire proposals as proposed by General de Gaulle. The people were not asked to decide on how the cease-fire was to be achieved. Therefore, Mr Speaker, Sir, the question to be put by the Government of Singapore to the people should also be just one question.

    The purpose of the Deputy Prime Minister's amendment is to ignore positively and openly the wishes of the people of Singapore at a future national referendum. I would ask the P.A.P. and the Alliance to name the countries in which more than one question was advanced for the people to decide, That is

Column: 851

why I say that the P.A.P. is more dictatorial than Hitler was and this is no exaggeration.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday the Minister for Culture criticised the amendment moved by the Member for Queenstown to delete the word "reunification". Perhaps he has learnt his logic from Alex Josey for having arrived at the conclusion that the Barisan Sosialis do not want to have reunification of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya. He advanced puerile arguments in the same way when he likened the Barisan Sosialis to the Dutch. This is only worth a smile. We are of the opinion that any constitutional proposals on a basis of inequality will not be conducive to the true spirit of reunification, especially when the White Paper has clearly shown that the merger proposals are not for what you can call reunification. The Minister for Culture has once again disclosed the P.A.P.'s trickery of deceiving the people.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Deputy Prime Minister, when he moved his amendment, said that the Barisan Sosialis in their desperation were trying to create suspicion, distrust and confusion among the people of Singapore in order to block the realisation of merger. He went on to say that this action of the Barisan Sosialis was not only childish and puerile but also dangerous and that it would lead to very regrettable consequences, such as the outbreak of racial conflict for which the Barisan Sosialis would be held fully responsible.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, from the speech of the Deputy Prime Minister, it would appear that the P.A.P. are bankrupt in their political theories. The poverty of the various races in Singapore can only be improved on the basis of a non-communal arrangement. In other words, it is only in a society where there is no exploitation of man by man that poverty can be abolished and there is prosperity.

    If any constitutional arrangement is based on equality of citizenship rights for all races, then there will be no racial conflict or racial inequality. The Barisan Sosialis have never done anything or said

Column: 852

anything to create racial conflict or suspicion among the people. Sir, it is necessary to unite the workers of all races and the intellectuals of all classes in Malaya in order to thwart any attempt to disrupt the unity of our people. This has been clearly stated in our manifesto when our Party was founded. Today, the people are mostly concerned with the question of whether they will be deprived of their citizenship rights and whether there will be any safeguards for their future generations. This fear of the people should not be overlooked by the Government.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I trust the hon. Member is not now embarking on a debate on citizenship. As I say, all these points can be mentioned in passing, but he must not enter into a debate or say anything which might open up a debate in regard to matters on which this Assembly has already come to a conclusion.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): I accept your ruling, Sir.

    The Deputy Prime Minister said that the P.A.P. will recklessly force the people of Singapore to swallow the poison given by them at all costs. I would like to remind the P.A.P. Government that they should shoulder the responsibility for all consequences.

    Sir, we firmly oppose the amendment of the Deputy Prime Minister. We cannot issue a blank cheque to be used by the P.A.P. especially in connection with the future national referendum. If the Government is sincere in wanting the people to decide on the future constitutional arrangements, then it should withdraw its amendment to the motion.

3.00 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, in debating the motion before the House only those people whose blood is dirty will have skin disease, and only those whose souls are filthy will make nonsensical speeches.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I have heard unparlimentary expressions in this Chamber but I think the expressions

Column: 853

which have just been used take the first prize! I would suggest that these expressions are completely unparliamentary and they ought to be withdrawn.

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed(In Malay): If you consider such expressions to be unparliamentary, I withdraw them.

    If we study the aim of the motion of the Member for Anson to which an amendment has been moved by the Government, it is an attempt to obtain cheap publicity in order to get the support of the masses and to create uncertainty in their minds so that they will hate the Government. When he moved his motion, I observed that he was pretending to be a genuine democratic fighter by alleging that parliamentary democracy would not be destroyed by the Communists but by the P.A.P. He also said that the present practices of the P.A.P. Government are of a dictatorial nature. I wish to emphasise that if the P.A.P. runs a dictatorial administration, the Member for Anson will not now be in this Chamber. History has shown us that in dictatorship countries-for example, in Germany - many people suffered to such an extent that even the skin of human beings was used to make shoes. But we can see in this Chamber the Member for Anson crowing as loud as he wishes, airing his views and throwing criticisms as much as he likes.

    The Member for Anson intimated that he sympathised with the Back benches of the Government by saying that they had been influenced by the Front benches of the Government. We would like to state once and for all that the stand of the Back benches of the Government is firm, unlike the wavering stand of the Member for Anson who at one time challenged our Prime Minister to go to the people but who subsequently did not carry out the challenge. We do not whisper among ourselves, unlike the Member for Anson who conversed in a whisper with the Member for Nee Soon when we were debating a certain issue once. That clearly shows that he has no firm stand of his own.

Column: 854

Mr Speaker, Sir, some Members of the Opposition have said that the stand of the Government can be likened to the dictatorship of Japan. If the attitude of the Government could be so likened, we would then see heads of people exhibited at street corners. But today the people are free to express their views in the true tradition of parliamentary democracy.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we should not say what we like as regards the referendum on merger with the Federation of Malaya. When we talk about reunification or merger, it means there are two things which should be agreed upon by two sides. If one side insists on its view only, then it means that it is forcing the other side to accept its view. On the issue of merger, we must try to understand the views of the other side in order to reach a mutual agreement. Then only can we come to a certain understanding. For instance, if the Barisan Sosialis really believed in complete merger, they should have the courage to move a positive amendment using the phrase "complete merger". But instead they have kept on harping on the White Paper on merger which has been accepted by the Assembly, and they are wavering in their stand.

    The Member for Queenstown said that he shared the sentiments expressed in the motion moved by the Member for Anson. This means that he agreed with the views expressed by the Member for Anson. They have said that they want complete merger outside this Assembly, but not in this Assembly.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday I heard the Member for Upper Serangoon saying that the P.A.P. have twisted and turned the merger issue into a reunification problem. I think there is no difference between merger and reunification, because Singapore originally was part of Malaya. Reunification means a return to the fold - except, of course, if the intention is to reunite Singapore with Taiwan or with some other country! Singapore and Malaya are one. If we talk about reunification, it, is not incorrect in the true sense of, the word, unless it is the intention of some people

Column: 855

to mislead the masses. If they cannot accept the word "reunification", then it is hard to understand why they support the motion moved by the Member for Anson in which the word "reunification" is used. They are speaking with their tongue in their cheek in order to confuse the people. It should be the responsibility of every Member of this Assembly to give a true picture of the situation to the people and not to twist the facts.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Did I hear the Member right when he said that the term "reunification" appeared in the motion standing in the name of the Member for Anson, because I cannot find the word "reunification" in that motion?

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): On a point of order, Sir. Perhaps I can be of assistance, Sir. You will find that the amendment as moved by me was,

    'That this House welcomes the Singapore National Referendum Bill in order to hold a referendum to ascertain the wishes of the people ...'-

    Mr Speaker: Order. I am talking about the motion. We have disposed of the Member for Anson's amendment. My question was whether the Parliamentary Secretary, by indicating that the term "reunification" was in the motion of the Member for Anson, meant it was in the motion standing in the name of the Member for Anson, or in some other motion, or possibly the amendment proposed by the Member for Anson which did not leave out the word. "reunification".

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed(In Malay): Sir, the word "reunification" was used in the amendment. I am only touching on it in passing. .1 was saying that some support the use of the term "reunification" while others object to its use.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the motion moved by the Member for Anson, to which an amendment has been moved by the Government, clearly shows that the mover is attempting to obtain cheap

Column: 856

publicity in order to get the support of the people and at the same time to confuse their thinking.

    Mr David Marshall: On a point of order, Sir. I seem to -

    Mr Speaker: Order. The Member for Anson should just rise and say, "On a point of order," because of the lapse of time in interpretation. So I have not really heard what the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister was going to say. The point of order being?

    Mr David Marshall: The point of order being that the Standing Order says that one should not question the motives of a Member of the Assembly in bringing matters before the Assembly. Am I not right, Sir?

    Mr Speaker: Possibly the Standing Order referred to is Standing Order 46 (6) which says:

    `No Member shall impute improper motives to any other Member.'

    I do not know whether the Member for Anson is alleging that the Parliamentary Secretary has imputed an improper motive.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, I suppose that is without question an allegation of improper motive.

    Mr Speaker: And the words used being?

    Mr David Marshall: The words being that I am seeking cheap publicity, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Well, I must confess that the Speaker has never been a politician, but I am sure politicians would like publicity, whether it is cheap or expensive!

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore National Referendum Bill was tabled in the Assembly and it is now to go to Select Committee. This clearly shows that it is the Government's intention to hold a referendum, otherwise there would be no purpose in tabling the Bill. If it is against the Standing Order, I do not wish to comment further, but everybody knows this. If the sex of a fish can

Column: 857

be identified in water, what more we who are politicians? We should not confuse the minds of the people, if we are true representatives of the people; and we should not fail to voice their views.

3.15 p.m.

    Mr S. T. Bani (Thomson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am quite sure that many people are perturbed over this talk of democracy which amounts to a big farce as propagated by the P.A.P. The issue is quite simple: whether the Government wants to seek the approval of the people on their White Paper proposals. And whether the Government is prepared to accept the wishes of the people as expressed in the referendum.

    Sir, the very fact that the Deputy Prime Minister, in moving his amendment, has conveniently left out the very last part of the motion moved by the Member for Anson, viz., "will act in accordance with the views of our citizens so expressed", is a clear indication that the Government has no intention whatsoever of accepting the views of the people if those views are going to be contrary to the Government's proposals for merger as contained in the White Paper.

    Sir, we have been accused of being people who want to wreck the parliamentary system. I am quite certain that anybody with an average intelligence will realise that the way the P.A.P. proposes to go about holding this referendum will, in fact, wreck the parliamentary system. It will make the word "democracy" a mockery. All that we have been saying is: here you have your proposals contained in the White Paper as adopted by this Assembly, with the support of the S.P.A. and the P.A.P. And we feel that the people must be asked whether they support these proposals or they do not. The question to be posed to the people should be one that is simple and that does not seek to confuse the people.

    I am sure we can all remember the confidence with which Government Members spoke during the debate on the White Paper. If they are that

Column: 858

confident, if they are quite sure that the only people who oppose the White Paper are the so-called Communists, and that everybody else wants merger on the terms proposed by the Government, then why are they afraid to pose a very simple question to the people?

    Mr Speaker: Order. The Member for Thomson is doing exactly what I said to the Member for Choa Chu Kang that he should not do, and that is to debate on why the White Paper should or should not be put to the people. The reason is that that question has already been debated and has been rejected by this Assembly. I have indicated that, for continuity of speech, the Member for Thomson can just mention the matter in passing, but not urge once again that the only question for the referendum should be the White Paper.

    Mr Bani: I was just going to mention that in passing, Sir. The point I want to stress is that if a referendum is held, it should not be merely for the sake of form. It should not be just to show that the Government wants to consult the people. But, in actual fact, it will merely be a form used to get the support of the people.

    Sir, it has already been pointed out that what the Government is thinking of is along the lines of posing two alternative questions. And in all likelihood, the two alternatives will be unacceptable alternatives. If the people are going to be asked to choose between two evils, then quite certainly there will be some people who will be uncertain. They may send in blank votes. And the Government has thought fit to have a proviso in the Referendum Bill couched -

    Mr Speaker: Order. The Member for Thomson is completely out of order. That particular clause in the Bill is now under consideration by the. Select Committee and he cannot refer to it.

    Mr Bani: What I do want to point out, Mr Speaker, Sir, is the motive of the Government in wanting to hold this referendum. It is not its genuine desire to consult the views of the people,

Column: 859

because they are committed to consult the people. They want to work out a form which is going to be used to bulldoze their White Paper proposals through.

    Sir, if the intention of the Government is not to accept the decision of the referendum, then the consequences are going to be very serious.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): So that you can start trouble!

    Mr Bani: Let me make it quite clear. It is not trouble created by individuals that I am talking about. There have been accusations that the Barisan Sosialis has been responsible for creating communal tension. The movers of the merger proposals have right from the very beginning approached the problem purely from a communal point of view. We all know that if today Singapore is not going to be accepted as a constituent unit like any other State in the Federation of Malaya, if the people of Singapore are not going to be accepted automatically as Federal citizens, it is because the majority of the people in Singapore are Chinese. This is a blatantly communal approach. And having made the approach right from the very beginning on a communal basis, and now giving the people the choice to reject categorically the proposals as contained in the White Paper which are based on inequity, it is inevitably going to create trouble. Whether this is said or not said is not very important. I refuse to believe that the people can be forced into accepting a constitutional arrangement, whereby they are going to be treated as second-class citizens. I wish to assure you again: I do not want to start and I am not going to start a debate on the merger issue. But it is pertinent, Sir, to mention this: in examining the motion before the House, the purpose in wanting to hold a referendum should be to determine whether the people support the P.A.P. proposals or not. And if the people do not support them, then they should not be proceeded with. As

Column: 860

I have said, if, firstly, the machinery provided for consulting the views of the people is going to be inadequate; secondly, the form in which the people are going to be asked to approve or disapprove the P.A.P. proposals is going to be inadequate; thirdly, if the Government is determined to push through this White Paper arrangement, irrespective of the desire of the people; then it does not take a superman to forecast that the repercussions are going to be serious. As I have said, the Government Members have always said that they are confident the people will support the White Paper. According to them, it is only the so-called Communists who oppose merger. In the words of some of the Government Ministers, there are only 300 Communists in Singapore.

    Mr Rajaratnam: You are a big boy now!

    Mr Bani: Surely, Sir, the Government is not suggesting now that it has lost the confidence of the voters they had in the past. I tell this to the Government benches, Sir - better not commit atrocities in the name of democracy. Sir, some of the worst atrocities in the world have been committed in the name of democracy. I am sure Members on the Government benches do not want to be democrats like Chiang Kai-shek, Syngman Rhee and so on and so forth. We do not want to say that we are genuine democrats and that we are defenders of the towers of parliamentary democracy, etc. It does not matter what we are called. But it is those honourable Members sitting on the opposite benches who have been saying that they are champions of democracy. Let us work out a simple, straight-forward arrangement so that you get the views of the people quite categorically. Do not tell them to choose between two evils and give them not even the alternative of putting a blank vote.

    Referenda held elsewhere in the world have always been, to the best of my knowledge, in the form of one simple question: "Do you support the Government's decision on this, or do you not?"

Column: 861

Yes or no. If the purpose is not genuinely to seek the views of the people but to force them to give support to the Government, then I say, Sir, this is not democracy. This is hypocrisy. I am sure, Mr Speaker, that we have all heard of the term "guided democracy" in this part of the world. What the P.A.P. Government is trying to practise is not even guided democracy. It is "guarded democracy".

    Sir, if ambitious men in an attempt to save their own political career want to try to bulldoze their constitutional arrangements through, the consequences are going to be serious. And let this be a warning. I say that whatever the consequences as a result of the acts of the Government, the responsibility should lie squarely on the shoulders of the men who hold the reins of government.

3.37 p.m.

    Mr S. V. Lingam (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to oppose the amendment moved by the Deputy Prime Minister. The original motion of the Member for Anson was to seek an assurance from the Assembly that there will be a referendum on merger. Sir, since my Party, the United People's Party, first called on the Government on 18th September, 1961, to refer their proposals to the people for decision in a referendum, the Government have made many pronouncements agreeing that there will be a referendum. But the Deputy Prime Minister's amendment goes one step further than the assurance on the referendum which the Member for Anson seeks. It is going to ask the Legislative Assembly to provide a cloak for the questions which the Government are going to frame in the referendum ballot paper. If the questions framed are unfair and undemocratic, the Government will try to seek cover by saying that the Legislative Assembly has approved them, which is far from the truth. What is meant by "the mode and manner of the inevitable reunification of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya"? The Deputy Prime Minister has not explained its meaning to us. However, from the speech of the

Column: 862

Minister for Culture, it seems to us that the voters will be asked to choose whether they want the P.A.P. merger proposals or the so-called Penang or Malacca type of merger. Is that what is meant by "the mode and manner of merger"? Does it mean that the people will have to choose between two types of merger, both of which they do not want? Mr Speaker. Sir, what the people want is a complete merger where all Singapore citizens, wherever they are born, automatically become Federal citizens. The net result of the amendment of the Deputy Prime Minister is to shift the emphasis on whether there is going to be a referendum on to a different issue. Wednesday, 18th April, 1962


    The following Question for Oral Answer stood on the Order Paper of 18th April, 1962 :-

Royal Singapore Golf Club


    "Mr David Marshall: To ask the Prime Minister what is the area occupied by the Royal Singapore Golf Club and the terms on which such lands are held.".

    The Prime Minister, not being present to answer the question, the following answer was supplied on 18th April, 1962, pursuant to Standing Order No. 20 (3):-

    "The Royal Singapore Golf Club occupies an area of approximately 270 acres out of a total of 7,573 acres of City Council catchment land. This is covered by two separate Agreements:-
